setup.question: What makes the protagonists become less concerned about being trapped by the beasts?
answers: They realized the beasts were not actual beasts, but were meant to seem real.
They realized that the beasts were too big to fit into the space they were in, so they could camp out in that spot indefinitely.

Text.text: currently based on the title "monster maker" it seems like the beasts were not real but made to look real. In order for this debate to move smoothly to whoever the honest debater is I would be more inclined to vote for you if you pull your most convincing quote and start off with that. From there if the dishonest debater cannot answer it'll be an easy win.
This is a very one and done debate. The beasts that seem highly vicious are 100% non-real.

First to clarify our main character Click Hathaway has a camera.This camera is ordinary, but it is our character's perception that is wrong and thus the camera resolves this. Here is the evidence that will end this debate in a single round:
. As you can see the monsters despite feeling very real and life-threatening to our characters, are not on the camera film. As such its clear something is creating monster illusions.

Though your intuition is right, judge, that the title confirms that the beasts aren't real, the characters' perceptions on this shift throughout the story in given moments. For example, even after their "discovery" that the beasts aren't real in the literal sense, Marnagan/Irish said
, because in that moment, it was real to him and
, that something being the beast. As Click said,
. They were less concerned about being trapped because they managed to find a spot where the beasts couldn't get to them

Ok wait at first I was leaning towards A but i wasn't sure but B did you just restate A's argument? cause you quoted that "as long as they believed in them they could have frightened us" which kindve plays into the whole idea that A is talking about that the beasts are not real. While your last quote would have won you the debate, or gotten you closer to confusing me I think since you explained A's point I am unsure. 

Debater A: if you can prove to me that that last quote is bad or not true do that, additional quotes that the monsters arent real would be helpful as well

Debater B: what is the purpose of the camera and are the monsters real

I hope the 15-85 for B is a mistake because I will end the debate here and now:

for 1, B can't even prove the key part of their quote about the camping out of the spot indefinitely. 
It's not in their opening speech because its not even in the story at all.

Now I will bring a final piece of evidence, that should make this a clean 99-1 for A.
. Here Marnagan, Click's companion/friend is originally frightened by the monster until Click makes him snap back into reality that its not real, which M agrees.

The beasts are not real, this debate is not about that--it's about why the protagonists became less concerned about the beasts, but A's speech simply harped on the real-not-real debate, which is not what this is about.

Bc simply because beasts weren't real didn't diminish the fact that the MCs, when not focused on that fact, would *see* them as real, and feel just as scared (this is an aspect central to the story, hence 'Monster Maker'). This explains A's quotes about them screaming to remind each other that they're not real because they continued to be scared even though they know the beasts weren't real. The real reason they were less concerned was because, as explained by my quotes, they had their first moments of reprieve in the cave.

wait it was a mistake omg - so sorry - I meant to put that in favor of A. That being said, A's let quote is a tough one to come back from. While I know B was trying to save themselves in the last speech they ended up just admitting to A's point by saying that the beasts aren't real.

answers.reason for outcome: The evidence was very much in the text for the honest answer

Accidentally voted for the wrong team during the debate. I think I had to take a little direction from A just because B's final speech started to confuse me (as it should). When they brought the debate back to the question at hand B's argumentation started to make sense. However A had a lot more convincing and logical evidence which is why I ended up voting for them. I generally vote with a full 99/1 confidence for the winning team however a little bit of sway from B made me lower my percentage.
better side, kind of one-sided question
